Albania: Communist Party of the Soviet Union chief Nikita Khrushchev delivered the speech "On the Personality Cult and its Consequences" in which he criticized his predecessor Joseph Stalin, and caused a chill in relations with Albania under the pro-Stalin Hoxha.
Argentina: INTA, the National Agricultural Technology Institute, is created
Australia:
Television in Australia is launched.
The 16th Summer Olympics is held in Melbourne
Performing artist Barry Humphries introduces Edna Everage to the Australian stage
Bangladesh: Bengali becomes one of the state languages of Pakistan.
Barbados: Election: Won by Barbados Labour Party-BLP, led by Grantley Adams.
Belgium:
Labour Treaty signed at The Hague establishing free movement of labour between Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, to come into force 1 November 1960.
Mining accident of Marcinelle claims 262 lives, including 136 Italian foreign workers
Brazil: Juscelino Kubitschek is inaugurated as the 21st President of Brazil.
Colombia: the Liberal Party headed by Alberto Lleras Camargo and the Conservative Party headed by Laureano Gómez signed an accord on 24 June 1956 to begin the National Front (Colombia).
Cuba: Autentico Assault on Goicuria Barracks in Matanzas fails. Ex-president Prío exiled to Miami. The yacht Granma sets out from Mexico to Cuba with 82 men on board, including Raúl Castro, Che Guevara and Camilo Cienfuegos. The Granma lands in Oriente Province.
Cyprus: Britain deported Makarios to the Seychelles in an attempt to quell the revolt.
Haiti: President Magloire relinquishes the presidency; President of the Supreme Court Joseph Nemours Pierre-Louis becomes provisional president of Haiti
India:
B. R. Ambedkar converted to Buddhism along with 600,000 followers.
B. R. Ambedkar died.
Indinesia:
The cabinet falls as a result of its policy toward the Dutch.
Indonesia unilaterally abrogates the Round Table Agreement signed with the Dutch in 1949.
Hatta resigns as vice-president.
Israel: Suez Crisis: In a broadcast speech, Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser gave a codeword order for the occupation and nationalization of the Suez Canal and the closure of the Straits of Tiran to Israeli shipping. Suez Crisis: The Israeli air force began bombing Egyptian forces in the Sinai Peninsula.
Malta: A referendum is held on the integration of Malta into the United Kingdom: 75% vote 'Yes'; however, the result is deemed to be questionable due to a boycott by 40% of the electorate in response to concerns raised by opposition parties and by the Catholic Church.
Philippine: Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN) is established by Lopez family. Death of Elpidio Quirino, former Philippine President Provincehood of Aklan (Republic Act No. 1414), separating from Capiz. Rizal Bill is passed into law amid opposition from Catholic Church.
Poland:
Death of Bolesław Bierut
Poznań 1956 protests
Polish October, return of Władysław Gomułka
Russia: At a closed session of the 20th Party Congress, Khrushchev read the "Secret Speech," On the Personality Cult and its Consequences, denouncing the actions of his predecessor Stalin. The speech weakened the hand of the Stalinists in the Soviet government. The Cominform was officially dissolved. Poznań 1956 protests: Poles upset with the slow pace of destalinization turned to protests, and then to violent riots. Poznań 1956 protests: Konstantin Rokossovsky, the Polish minister of defense, ordered the military in to end the riots. At least 74 civilians were killed. The Karelo-Finnish SSR became the Karelian ASSR of the Russian SFSR. The liberal Władysław Gomułka was elected leader of the Polish Communist party. 1956 Hungarian Revolution: A small pro-Gomułka demonstration in Budapest expanded into a 100,000 head protest. The protestors marched on Parliament; when they were fired on by the Hungarian Security Police, they turned violent and began to arm themselves. An emergency meeting of the Central Committee appointed the reformist Imre Nagy Prime Minister. 1956 Hungarian Revolution: Hungary under Nagy withdrew from the Warsaw Pact. 1956 Hungarian Revolution: A Soviet invasion, involving infantry, artillery, airstrikes, and some 6,000 tanks entered Budapest. 2,500 Hungarians were killed in the ensuing battle. 1956 Hungarian Revolution: Pro-Soviet János Kádár announced the formation of a new "Revolutionary Worker-Peasant Government," with himself as Prime Minister and leader of the Communist Party. Cuban Revolution: Fidel Castro and his followers in the 26 July Movement landed in Cuba. Angolan War of Independence: Two Angolan independence movements united to form the Marxist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
Singapore:
David Marshall appeals to the United Kingdom for full self-government, but resigns when he fails. Lim Yew Hock takes over as Chief Minister.
Riots by pro-communist Chinese school students occur when government closes down a student union on 24 September 1956.
Dunman High School (formally known as Singapore Government Chinese Middle School), became the first Chinese secondary school established by the government.
